title: Hunt & Hess Classification of Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
description: Classifies severity of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage based on clinical presentation to predict mortality and guide surgical risk assessment. Uses neurological symptoms and level of consciousness to assign grades I-V.

parameters.name: serious_systemic_disease
parameters.description: Presence of serious systemic disease (hypertension, diabetes, severe arteriosclerosis, chronic pulmonary disease, severe vasospasm on angiography)

ranges.interpretation: Asymptomatic or minimal headache and slight nuchal rigidity. Excellent prognosis with ~70% survival rate. Low surgical risk. Early intervention generally recommended.
Moderate to severe headache, nuchal rigidity, no neurologic deficit other than cranial nerve palsy. Good prognosis with ~60% survival rate. Reasonable surgical candidate.
Drowsiness, confusion, or mild focal deficit. Fair prognosis with ~50% survival rate. Higher surgical risk, careful evaluation needed.
Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity and vegetative disturbances. Poor prognosis with ~40% survival rate. High surgical risk.
Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity, moribund appearance. Very poor prognosis with ~10% survival rate. Extremely high surgical risk, intervention often futile.

references: Hunt WE, Hess RM. Surgical risk as related to time of intervention in the repair of intracranial aneurysms. J Neurosurg. 1968 Jan;28(1):14-20.
Hunt WE, Kosnik EJ. Timing and perioperative care in intracranial aneurysm surgery. Clin Neurosurg. 1974;21:79-89.

Oshiro EM, Walter KA, Piantadosi S, Witham TF, Tamargo RJ. A new subarachnoid hemorrhage grading system based on the Glasgow Coma Scale: a comparison with the Hunt and Hess and World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies Scales in a clinical series. Neurosurgery. 1997 Jul;41(1):140-7.
formula: Grade based on clinical presentation: I (asymptomatic/minimal headache), II (moderate-severe headache, nuchal rigidity), III (drowsiness/confusion/mild deficit), IV (stupor/hemiparesis), V (coma/decerebrate). Add one grade if serious systemic disease present.
notes: Originally developed in 1968 by Hunt and Hess, modified in 1974 to include grades 0 and Ia
Higher grades correlate with increased mortality and surgical risk
Inter-observer variability is high (Îº ~0.48), reassessment recommended
Assessment at 48 hours post-admission may provide better prognostication than initial assessment
Serious systemic disease increases grade by one level
Should be used in conjunction with other clinical factors and imaging findings
Modified Hunt-Hess scales have been proposed to improve discrimination
Not applicable to traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage
Correlates well with World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) scale
